com.threerings.opengl.gui.background
Class ImageBackground

java.lang.Object
  com.threerings.opengl.gui.background.Background
      com.threerings.opengl.gui.background.ImageBackground

public class ImageBackground
extends Background

Supports image backgrounds in a variety of ways. Specifically:

  • Centering the image either horizontally, vertically or both.
  • Scaling the image either horizontally, vertically or both.
  • Tiling the image either horizontally, vertically or both.
  • Framing the image in a fancy way: the background image is divided into nine sections (three across and three down), the corners are rendered unscaled, the central edges are scaled in one direction and the center section is scaled in both directions. 
     +----------+----------------+----------+
 | unscaled |  <- scaled ->  | unscaled |
 +----------+----------------+----------+
 |    ^     |       ^        |    ^     |
 |  scaled  |  <- scaled ->  |  scaled  |
 |    v     |       v        |    v     |
 +----------+----------------+----------+
 | unscaled |  <- scaled ->  | unscaled |
 +----------+----------------+----------+

Constructor Detail

ImageBackground

public ImageBackground(int mode,
                       Image image)
Creates an image background in the specified mode using the supplied image.

ImageBackground

public ImageBackground(int mode,
                       Image image,
                       Insets frame)
Creates an image background in the specified mode using the supplied image and the special frame. This should only be used if one of the framing modes is being used and the supplied frame will be used instead of the default frame which divides the image in thirds.

ImageBackground

public ImageBackground(int mode,
                       Image image,
                       Insets frame,
                       int anchor)
Creates an image background in the specified mode using the supplied image and the special frame. This should only be used if one of the framing modes is being used and the supplied frame will be used instead of the default frame which divides the image in thirds.
